County Economic Indicators Amelia Island Chamber Music Festival Selects Robyn Lamp as its New Executive Director Robyn Lamp, New Executive Director for Amelia Island Chamber Music Festival AMELIA ISLAND, Fla.¬†‚Äì¬†Oct. 1, 2024¬†‚Äì Amelia Island Chamber Music Festival ‚Äôs Board of Directors named Robyn Lamp the festival‚Äôs new executive director. The festival is one of the nation's most prestigious chamber music series, known for its first-class performances and music education programs. ‚ÄúAfter an extensive search, we are most pleased to welcome Robyn Lamp as our executive director,‚Äù Board President Emma Mills Bledsoe said. ‚ÄúHer knowledge, experience and pursuit of excellence in bringing music to our community, and now to our organization, will ensure that we continue to be an integral part of the cultural fabric of the Southeast.‚Äù Board members said Lamp‚Äôs experience as an arts administrator and classical musician, combined with her passion for promoting classical music in her community, will help advance the festival's mission. Lamp will begin her new position in time to oversee the 24th season, including performances by Mark and Maggie O‚ÄôConnor, pianist Jeremy Denk, the Tak√°cs Quartet, classical guitarist Sharon Isbin, and others. ‚ÄúWe are thrilled that Robyn is joining our team to present the best musicians in the world on Amelia Island at the festival,‚Äù Artistic Director William Ransom said. ‚ÄúWith her extensive and administrative background, we are poised for a great future ahead.‚Äù Lamp is currently IlluminArts‚Äô company manager in Miami. In 2021, she co-founded Amelia Island Opera and serves as secretary of its Board of Directors. When Lamp assumes her new role on Oct. 21, she will manage day-to-day operations and work alongside the Board to lead fundraising, marketing and community engagement efforts. ‚ÄúBefore I made Amelia Island my home in 2020, I would attend Amelia Island Chamber Music Festival concerts as a visitor,‚Äù Lamp said. ‚ÄúI was always excited and impressed by the high-quality programming presented by Amelia Island Chamber Music Festival. I am truly humbled to have been entrusted with the responsibility of advancing the mission of this great organization.‚Äù Lamp is a classically trained opera singer with a master‚Äôs degree in music from Louisiana State University. Highlights of her freelance opera and choral career include singing as the soprano soloist in Verdi‚Äôs Requiem¬†at Carnegie Hall and Mechanics Hall, an ensemble member of Grammy Award-nominated Seraphic Fire, the title role in Puccini‚Äôs Tosca¬†with the Naples Philharmonic and Adele in Bellini‚Äôs rarely heard Il Pirata¬†with the Orchestra of St. Luke's at Caramoor Summer Music Festival. The Amelia Island Chamber Music Festival was founded in 2001 by Christopher Rex, a vacationer on Amelia Island and principal cellist of the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra. Now entering its 24th season, the festival has developed into one of the nation's most prestigious events of its kind. Grants from the Florida Division of Cultural Affairs, Community Foundation for Northeast Florida and National Endowment for the Arts help support the festival, along with generous contributions from sponsors, donors and dedicated volunteers. Music education for concert audiences, students and aspiring young musicians has been a core mission of the festival since its founding. In addition to the Beth Newdome Fellowship and master classes, the organization launched two new education programs in 2019: the Christopher Rex Spring Institute and the String Education Program. The array of internationally acclaimed artists who have headlined the festival includes Yo-Yo Ma, Itzhak Perlman, Hilary Hahn, Pinchas Zukerman, Joshua Bell, Chick Corea, B√©la Fleck, Chris Thile, Emanuel Ax, Valentina Lisitsa and Wynton Marsalis. Previous star-studded headliners also include Grammy Award-winning violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter, bluegrass singer Ricky Skaggs, and soprano Ren√©e Fleming. The acclaimed Dover Quartet was named the organization‚Äôs first quartet-in-residence. The festival has enjoyed a glorious past, and its future is even more exciting. ¬© 2025 Nassau County Chamber of Commerce | Site by GrowthZone location 961687 Gateway Blvd., Suite 101-G Fernandina Beach, FL 32034 phone (904) 261-3248 email info@NassauCountyFLChamber.com facebook twitter youtube LinkedIn #WeAreTheChamber Interested in Membership? His music blends swing, bebop, and Caribbean rhythms into a performance that will leave you breathless. And that‚Äôs not all‚Ä¶ sharing the stage will be the powerhouse Les DeMerle Jazz Quintet. This is your chance to experience one of today‚Äôs premier jazz voices right here at home! AICMF Scores a Hit at Boys & Girls Clubs ‚Äì Boys & Girls Clubs of Nassau County About Us BGCN Foundation Our Leadership Team Our Programs 2024-2025 After School Program News & Events BGCNCF News 19th Annual Gala Our Clubs Miller Freedom Center Roberts Learning & Achievement Center Get Involved Become a Guardian Leave a Legacy Ways to Give Contact Us Donate Now About Us BGCN Foundation Our Leadership Team Our Programs 2024-2025 After School Program News & Events BGCNCF News 19th Annual Gala Our Clubs Miller Freedom Center Roberts Learning & Achievement Center Get Involved Become a Guardian Leave a Legacy Ways to Give Contact Us Donate Now 2018 Amelia Island Chamber Music Festival AICMF Scores a Hit at Boys & Girls Clubs Press Release Submitted by Alan Donaldson When Ms. Emma Bledsoe of the Amelia Island Music Festival called to suggest a concert for the youngsters at Boys & Girls Clubs of Nassau County, the Clubs staff knew something special was¬†on the way! So, on April 16 over 100 lucky members of the Boys and Girls Clubs were delighted when they gathered for the concert at the Roberts Learning and Achievement Center in Fernandina Beach. The concert highlighted The Grascals, a cutting-edge, modern bluegrass band, known for presenting a unique sound. They have appeared on national media, such as The Tonight Show with Jay Leno and CBS The Talk, and the band has performed over 150 times at the Grand Ole Opry. ‚ÄúThe members absolutely loved it,‚Äù said David Bryan, Unit Director of the Roberts Center. ‚ÄúWe try to introduce the members to as many educational and cultural experiences as possible, so we were thrilled when The Chamber Music Festival reached out to us to offer this concert.‚Äù The youngsters didn‚Äôt just listen to the band but also participated in an interactive musical experience. ‚ÄúEverybody had a chance to play one of the instruments,‚Äù said Danielle Albert, a Club¬†member ‚ÄúAnd the band played each instrument separately, so we could hear what each one sounded like. It was a lot of fun; I feel like I learned a lot!‚Äù The Roberts Center is looking forward to inviting and providing similar experiences and performances this summer during Boys and Girls Clubs Summer Academy from Monday, June 4¬†to Monday, August 6. Call Sherryl Smith at (904) 261-1075 to join the Miller Freedom Center on Old Nassauville Road. To enroll at Roberts Learning and Achievement Center on Lime Street in¬†Fernandina Beach, call David Bryan at (904) 491-9102. (Photo Caption: Daylee Abilar, a member of the Roberts Center, steps up to learn how to play the¬†violin from one of The Grascals.)
